snippet: Research suggests President Obama’s mixed-race heritage can still be a powerful factor in economically distressed regions with high proportions of white working-class residents.
abstract: Research suggests that for those in economically distressed regions with high proportions of white working-class residents, Pres Obama’s mixed-race heritage can still be a powerful factor; in interviews with voters in Steubenville, Ohio, some people cited race, but the main quarrels voters have with Obama in this staunchly Democratic area include his opposition to the Keystone pipeline, and the economy.

byline.contributor: Jeff Zeleny contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Research suggests President Obama’s mixed-race heritage can still be a powerful factor in economically distressed regions with high proportions of white working-class residents.

headline.main: 4 Years Later, Race Is Still Issue for Some Voters
headline.print_headline: 4 Years Later, Race Is Still Issue for Some Voters
